questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HSV 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

options.label: D
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.correct_answer: A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.
  • • Option A. Chemotherapy:
  • • Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.
  • • Option B. Brachytherapy:
  • • Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.
  • • Option D. Surgery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.
  • ➤ Staging of CA Cervix
  • ➤ TREATMENT
  • ➤ Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1 Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4
  • ➤ Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • ➤ Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4
  • ➤ Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.
  • ➤ The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancer? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Platinum-refractory disease : This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all. Platinum-resistant disease : This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis. Platinum-sensitive disease : This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.
  • • Platinum-refractory disease : This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all.
  • • Platinum-refractory disease
  • • Platinum-resistant disease : This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis.
  • • Platinum-resistant disease
  • • Platinum-sensitive disease : This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.
  • • Platinum-sensitive disease
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months : This statement is incorrect. If the recurrence occurs more than 12 months after treatment, it is considered platinum-sensitive, not resistant.
  • • Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months
  • • Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months : This statement is not a recognized classification. The classification focuses on the 6-month mark to distinguish between resistant and sensitive.
  • • Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Platinum-sensitive recurrent ovarian cancer is characterized by a recurrence occurring more than 6 months after completing primary therapy.
  • ➤ Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15 th edition pg 1387
  • ➤ Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15 th edition pg 1387

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes with excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge from the ear and HbA1c of 10. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Necrotizing otitis externa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a diabetic patient presenting with excruciating ear pain and bloody otorrhea, the diagnosis of necrotizing otitis externa should be considered, especially when the patient has a significantly elevated HbA1c, indicating poor glycemic control.

questions.text: Match the following positions of the appendix: ( INICET MAY 2023) Subcaecal Retrocaecal Inside the pelvis Paracaecal
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Isospora

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria: (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Single positive blood culture for HACK group is a major criterion

options.label: B
options.text: Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion

options.label: D
options.text: Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detection of C. Burnetti in a single blood culture is a major criterion for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis due to the organism's strong association with this disease, despite being difficult to culture.

questions.text: The most potent natural estrogen is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Estradiol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen, especially during a woman’s reproductive years, due to its high receptor affinity and significant physiological effects

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is conscious, BP is 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Needle thoracostomy

questions.text: Which receptor plays a crucial role in glucose uptake by skeletal muscles? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GLUT 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter responsible for insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal muscles, as well as in cardiac muscles and adipose tissues . Upon insulin binding, GLUT 4 translocates to the cell membrane, allowing glucose to enter the cells and be utilized for energy or stored as glycogen. This process is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels postprandially (after meals).
  • • skeletal muscles, as well as in cardiac muscles and adipose tissues
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. GLUT 1: GLUT 1 is involved in basal glucose uptake and is widely distributed in tissues such as the brain, placenta, kidneys, and red blood cells.
  • • Option A. GLUT 1:
  • • Option B. GLUT 2: GLUT 2 is found in the liver, ancreas, intestines, and kidneys, playing a role in glucose absorption, glycogen formation, insulin secretion, and reabsorption processes.
  • • Option B. GLUT 2:
  • • Option C. GLUT 3: GLUT 3, similar to GLUT 1, is involved in basal glucose uptake and is primarily located in the brain, placenta, and kidneys.
  • • Option C. GLUT 3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GLUT Transporters
  • ➤ GLUT Transporters

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of persistent fatigue. The physician is concerned about a particular condition and orders an on-site diagnostic test to evaluate further. The test, known to have a sensitivity of 98%, returns a negative result. Based on the high sensitivity, what is the most likely implication of this negative test outcome for the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population.

options.label: C
options.text: It is less likely that the patient has the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is less likely that the patient has the disease.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is less likely that the patient has the disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.
  • ➤ A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/µl. The most likely diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Red degeneration of fibroid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Red degeneration - occurs mostly in pregnancy. Due to thrombosis of capsular veins.
  • • Red degeneration
  • • Patient presents with tense, tender abdomen with fever. After excluding other obstetric complications (e.g.- abruption, appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis) Treatment: Symptomatic - hydration, rest and analgesia Surgical management AVOIDED
  • • Patient presents with tense, tender abdomen with fever.
  • • After excluding other obstetric complications (e.g.- abruption, appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis)
  • • Treatment: Symptomatic - hydration, rest and analgesia
  • • Surgical management AVOIDED
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pre-term labor : This is unlikely, as in preterm labor, the pain isn’t acute severe. It will be increasing in intensity and frequency and occurring at regular intervals. Preterm labor is also associated with cervical dilatation and effacement
  • • Option B. Pre-term labor
  • • Option C. Torsion of Fibroid : This can happen in a pedunculated subserous fibroid but is quite a rare occurrence, It will be additionally associated with vomiting and will require surgical management
  • • Option C. Torsion of Fibroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Red degeneration of fibroid during pregnancy presents with acute severe pain, and symptomatic treatment is the primary approach, avoiding surgical intervention.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 275, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 275, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6 th edition

questions.text: Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules? ( INICET Nov 2022) 1. Spermatogonia 2. Primary spermatocyte 3. Spermatid 4. Spermatozoa 5. Myoepithelial cell

  • ➤ Spermatogonia
  • ➤ Primary spermatocyte
  • ➤ Spermatid
  • ➤ Spermatozoa

questions.text: A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below: ( INICET Nov 2021) Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: B
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

options.label: C
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Left Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 24, 25
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: While preparing a slide for histopathological examination (HPE), a box-like gross appearance is seen in the scanner view. In which of the following conditions is this seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Morphea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Morphea, a localized form of scleroderma, is identified by a box-like or squared-off appearance on histopathological slides due to marked collagen sclerosis in the dermis.

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the ENT OPD with complaints of abnormal noise during breathing, the severity of which increases during crying. On examination, inspiratory stridors are heard and on laryngoscopy, the following finding is seen. The diagnosis would be? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The baby presents with abnormal noise during breathing that worsens with crying, and inspiratory stridor, indicating an upper airway issue. The laryngoscopy image shows an omega-shaped epiglottis, which is characteristic of laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants and results from the collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Congenital laryngeal web: A congenital laryngeal web would present with a hoarse cry and respiratory distress due to the fusion of the vocal cords. The airway would be significantly compromised, as shown below.
  • • Option B. Congenital laryngeal web:
  • • Option C. Congenital subglottic stenosis: Subglottic stenosis would show a narrowed subglottic area below the vocal cords, which is not consistent with the omega-shaped epiglottis seen in the image.
  • • Option C. Congenital subglottic stenosis:
  • • Option D. Congenital bilateral choanal atresia: Choanal atresia involves the blockage of the nasal passages and presents with difficulty breathing, particularly while feeding, but does not typically present with the findings of an omega-shaped epiglottis or inspiratory stridor.
  • • Option D. Congenital bilateral choanal atresia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and is identified by the presence of an omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

questions.text: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes? (NEET PG 2018)

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This is due to inhibition of_____ by aspirin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thromboxane Synthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspirin inhibits thromboxane synthesis by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to reduced platelet aggregation and an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Desflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Desflurane is not typically used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its pungent nature, which can cause significant airway irritation and laryngospasm.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with dysphagia to solids, weight loss and regurgitation. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ca Esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an elderly smoker presenting with dysphagia to solids, weight loss, and regurgitation, Ca esophagus should be considered as the probable diagnosis.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kata thermometer

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Performing an operation while under the influence of alcohol and causing harm to a patient constitutes criminal negligence, which is tried in a criminal court and can result in imprisonment and fines.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021) Albert's stain- I Acid alcohol Gram's iodine Safranin Methylene blue Crystal violet Carbol fuschin Acetone
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

questions.text: As per WHO, the definition of blindness is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blindness, as defined by the WHO, is visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes in with a grayish-white vaginal discharge. Upon conducting a gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are observed. What are clue cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.correct_answer: B. Epithelial cells covered by bacteria
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by bacteria, and their presence is indicative of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with annular lesions on the skin. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular lesions? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urticaria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is characterized by transient, well-circumscribed, erythematous, and edematous plaques that can be pruritic.
  • • These lesions typically appear and disappear within a few hours and do not usually form annular (ring-shaped) patterns. Urticaria can be triggered by various factors including allergens, stress, or physical stimuli, but the lesions themselves are generally not annular.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tinea corporis : This is a dermatophyte infection that commonly presents as annular, scaly plaques with a well-defined edge and central clearing. These ring-like lesions are characteristic of tinea infections.
  • • Option A. Tinea corporis
  • • Option B. Porokeratosis : This is a disorder of keratinization that presents with annular plaques with a distinct ridge-like border. The characteristic lesion of porokeratosis is an annular plaque with a raised, ridge-like border and central atrophy.
  • • Option B. Porokeratosis
  • • Option C. Pityriasis rosea : This condition often begins with a single herald patch followed by the development of multiple oval, scaly lesions that may have a ring or annular appearance. The distribution is often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the back.
  • • Option C. Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urticaria is characterized by transient erythematous plaques that do not typically present as annular lesions, unlike conditions such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serotonin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.
  • • Gastric Acid Secretion:
  • • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl). Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.
  • • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • • Parietal Cells:
  • • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.
  • • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells:
  • • Stimulation of ECL Cells:
  • • Stimulation of ECL Cells:
  • • Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.
  • • Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  • • Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  • • Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.
  • • Role of Serotonin:
  • • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.
  • • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.
  • • Serotonin:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option A. Gastrin:
  • • Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option B. Histamine:
  • • Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option C. Acetylcholine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text: What is/are correct statement(s) regarding skeletal muscle? ( INICET May 2023) Extracellular calcium entry is important in the skeletal muscle contraction. Calcium is mainly released from mitochondria. Calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Voltage-gated calcium channel on sarcolemma has no role in excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Only 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is essential for skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence. Lysis of bacterial cell Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria SDS-PAGE Hybridization Protein elution/extraction Expression of protein (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The steps of Recombinant DNA technology for expressing a gene of interest for production of a desired protein in E. coli cell.
  • • The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:
  • • The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:
  • • b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli. f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells. a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein. c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis. d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization. e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.
  • • b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli.
  • • b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria:
  • • f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells.
  • • f) Expression of protein:
  • • a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein.
  • • a) Lysis of bacterial cell:
  • • c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis.
  • • c) SDS-PAGE:
  • • d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization.
  • • d) Hybridization:
  • • e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.
  • • e) Protein elution/extraction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ References: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 432-438

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Paracrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.
  • • An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Autocrine : Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.
  • • Option B. Autocrine
  • • Option C. Endocrine : Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.
  • • Option C. Endocrine
  • • Option D. Merocrine : Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.
  • • Option D. Merocrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh

options.label: B
options.text: Referral centre for 2- 3 primary health centers

options.label: C
options.text: No sub-district and district hospitals present in the area

options.label: D
options.text: Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

questions.correct_answer: D. Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shock is a critical and life-threatening manifestation of pituitary apoplexy that arises from acute adrenal insufficiency. Immediate recognition and treatment with IV glucocorticoids and fluids are essential to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications. This condition is diagnosed via imaging, typically an MRI, and may require surgical intervention depending on the severity and the presence of neurological symptoms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Pituitary tumor syndromes/Page no 2897

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a documented 20-year history of alcohol abuse, consuming approximately 500 ml of alcohol daily, presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of disorientation, sensation of insects crawling on the skin, and severe agitation. Given this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that presents with disorientation, hallucinations, and agitation, typically occurring 48-72 hours after the last drink

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment protocol for plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females in the 1st trimester with complaints of headache and fever?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chloroquine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females, especially in the first trimester, the recommended treatment is chloroquine.
  • • For vivax and ovale malaria, the treatment of choice is chloroquine along with primaquine. However, in pregnancy primaquine is contraindicated.
  • • For vivax and ovale malaria, the treatment of choice is chloroquine along with primaquine.
  • • However, in pregnancy primaquine is contraindicated.
  • • Since the specifically asks about the treatment protocol for a pregnant female in the first trimester with vivax malaria, the appropriate treatment would be chloroquine alone, without primaquine.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. ART combined therapy - This option is incorrect because artemisinin-based combination therapy (ART) is the treatment of choice for falciparum and malariae malaria, not vivax malaria in pregnancy.
  • • Option
  • • A. ART combined therapy
  • • Option B. Quinine - This option is incorrect because quinine is not the recommended treatment for vivax malaria in pregnancy.
  • • Option
  • • B. Quinine -
  • • Option D. Chloroquine + Primaquine - This option is incorrect because primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • • Option
  • • D. Chloroquine + Primaquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment Protocol
